commentBody: Well that was fast - no resistance at all. I was a little concerned when I saw the choppiness of the grid that it would be a festival of crosswordese.

Sarah and Amie,
That's quite the photo on xwordinfo.com!

GIVE ME A HAND sort of reminded me of a funny scene from the movie Arthur with Dudley Moore. His dinner partner asks if Arthur would take her hand. His response is priceless üòÇ https://youtu.be/fojX7Ip4jSs?si=snsKltodRZDsthdp I love when a puzzle takes me way back. I was all of 11 years old when that movie came out and that line has stuck with me to this day. Thank you, Sarah and Amie for that trip down memory lane.

This was a pleasant enough Tuesday. It scored points with me by highlighting John McPhee, one of the most entertaining writers of non-fiction in  English.  McPhee had a great gift of finding the interesting in any subject, and the greater gift of being able to coax stories out of people he met from just about any walk of life.  The book highlighted in the puzzle, Coming Into The Country, is a complex portrait of many aspects of life in Alaska. I‚Äôve read it at least four times.  Other books about the New Jersey Pine Barrens, life on a Hebridean island, Princeton basketball player, Bill Bradley, tectonic geology, oranges, and birch bark canoes, to name a few, are all great reads.

I highly recommend the documentary movie, Don't Stop Believin': Everyman's Journey It's the story of Arnel Pineda joining the band Journey (wordplay photo) Here's the trailer: https://youtu.be/yKv93LcfLOI?si=P7BCgAxw4KHy5UNw

Starting out, 1A could have been ZIP, but a quick look at 1D made me realize it had to be VIM.  For 17A, I briefly had POwER PLAYER, until I realized that 3D MAwE... didn't look right. I had the EI of 21A and still didn't realize it was EILISH, but a few more crosses made that obvious.  I sailed through to the bottom.  I didn't know MCPHEE, but the crosses filled it in.  I managed, despite doing the lower third almost completely via Across answers, not to notice ST. LEO there, but if I hadn't gotten it entirely via the crosses, the words "Catholic" and "lion" in the clue make it a gimme, even if I'd never heard of the place. 

Overall, another easy puzzle; completed it 10.8% faster than my Tuesday average.

Some nitlets, though:

Again, the formal name is PANERA Bread.  Yes, I know, even their own commercials call it just PANERA, but it still is an (Informal) usage.  And isn't it more of a fast casual restaurant than a bakery chain?  (Yes, I know you can buy a bag of baked goods to go.)

Also, NEE means "born," not just [Formerly named].  You can't say "Jacqueline Onassis, NEE Kennedy," only "NEE Bouvier."  (Yes, Simpsons fans, that's where Marge's maiden name comes from.)

Neither of these things make their clues wrong, just a little askew.  Please don't tell me the clue's fine.  I had no trouble with either, but I think that if there's no deliberate misdirection, clues should be accurate.

Nice theme today, fortunately for me my love for Toy Story gave me 37A immediately, which in turn helped a lot with getting the theme. 

On the other hand I struggled with the SW corner, being unfamiliar with QVC, HSN or MCPHEE, I had to make a few guesses there.

This was a breezy theme, I liked the varied versions of hand and especially loved MRSPOTATOHEAD, both the entry and the clue. TIL CLAPOMETER. I have flashbacks to Madge the Manicurist from the old Palmolive commercials who I guess didn‚Äôt fit (showing my age‚Äî‚ÄúYou‚Äôre soaking in it!‚Äù) I also learned about John McPhee‚ÄîI love it when two stacked related clues pop up like that.

I have great memories of ALVIN and the Chipmunks and Don‚Äôt Tell MAMA from Cabaret (also showing my age). On the flip side I have nothing against Taylor Swift but can we retire the ERA clues finally? I think we‚Äôve beaten that horse one too many times.

Great puzzle, perfect Tuesday strength, lovely theme, nicely. clued. No complaints, and no eulogies or dirges for the CDC. 

Daniel Day-Lewis / Daniel Dae Kim. I'll get it straight yet! I imagine (if there's a way of measuring this), that this grid has way more "AE" appearances than average, perhaps even an Olympic record: NAE NAE, AERIES, DAE, and RAE. Too bad Fannie Mae didn't make an appearance. Thinking back on previous commentaries from months back, particularly from prickly Glaswegians, regarding the use of the word "nae" in conversational Scottish, I predict that some day "Nae Nae" will be clued as [Said no Scotsman, emphatically, ever].

Sweet puzzle. It did indeed cheer me up.
I realky enjoyed Myq Kaplan's column today, and yesterday's was very good, too. So far he's my favorite of the Wordplay guest columnists. üëç

I'd like to thank Ms. Sinclair and Ms. Walker for this fine puzzle. Let's give them a big hand! Let's also, everybody, put our hands up in the air for Kool and the Gang and LADIES" NIGHT: https://youtu.be/iAH9tY7ehhk?si=w89fdSQBIxcPDeAb (And I'd also like to take this opportunity to welcome back Art DECO. It's been a while since we've last seen ya...)
Nice one, especially like the clue for Mrs Potato Head!

An unpopular character who might ask ‚Äúgive me a hand‚Äù is the PHLEBOTOMIST. 
Most people would probably rather hang out with MRS POTATO HEAD!
Catholic U mascot is a cardinal not a lion

1:35 over my personal best. 4:45 under my average. Nifty little puzzle. Nice mixture of music ERAs from Cabaret to Phantom and ALVIN to EILISH. Answers like NAENAE and MCPHEE were easily filled in with crosses.

So if you‚Äôre of an age whereby you‚Äôve watched Toy Story and ALVIN and the chipmunks with your kids, know some Latin and Hesiod‚Äôs theogony, have read comics in a paper, read the New Yorker, are aware of anthropology, know the most eastern and western state and the one that would be wrong to guess for eastern, made model aeroplanes, and Billie EILISH then this was a breeze. 

Thanks to the setters and the editors

I'm a newbie (six months) but today makes three days in a row with no lookups. 

So you 'll probably all say it's too easy!!!
I know the puzzle freaks out about mentioning anything that's not current pop culture anymore but they still make Alvin and the Chipmunks movies. Doesn't really need the "old" hedge
No angry eyes needed today. Now where did I put my extra pair of shoes!? Delightful.

Nothing plodding about this one, just solid clues, with clever answers in the grid, and enough spice to make it interesting, the ideal Tuesday.

The Clap-O-Meter needle would confirm that!  

Thank you, Sarah and Amie, for giving us such an entertaining puzzle.
Jesus, that was a lot of trivia for a Tuesday. I barely made it without lookups. Way to kiII my enjoyment of a solve.
Hows mrs potato head connected with revealer? Havent seen the toy story series.

If you‚Äôre me, any puzzle that features MRS POTATOHEAD and CLAPOMETER is a winner. Thanks Sarah and Amie! This was a fine Tuesday puzzle with a little extra sparkle.

I‚Äôve also enjoyed Myq‚Äôs columns. And somehow I feel like it‚Äôs more fun to say Mike when it‚Äôs spelled Myq. (No offense to all other Mikes regardless of spelling, especially not our resident punster Mike from Munster.)

When actors receive a hand, they take a bow. That's just applause and effect.

(I only post this for special ovations.)
Delightful.

great puzzle - is there a way they could change to a visual celebration at the end of the solve instead of the unmastered sound jingle that blows up in our earbuds when we are listening to music or other things while we solve - nobody just sits and solves the puzzle we are listening to music or even chatting with people my earbuds beg thee - stop this pavlovian madness just make it a visual kudos grazie mille' https://linktr.ee/glassjonespiano

I liked this one! I think my favorite clue was the one for MRSPOTATOHEAD. Imagine packing extra eyes. Made me laugh.

John MCPHEE is a gifted author, a favorite among geologists. His first geology themed book that everyone I knew read was Basin and Range, about Nevada and Utah. My favorite, however, was Rising from the Plains. I read it while living in Wyoming, and its sense of place was extraordinary. At the center of the book is a geologist born in Wyoming. His life, and those of his ancestors, paints a vivid picture of this beautiful state.

As someone has mentioned, it's the little initialisms that are most frustrating for the non-local solvers - ABA, HSN, NIH. 

Otherwise, very pleasant.

Many people thought Sunday was too easy; if you want to try a fun (IMO) and more challenging Sunday, I recommend March 12, 1995 (I'm working my way thru the archives).

It's a puzzle celebrating the 50,000th issue of the NYT and many long answers are NYT headlines, clued by their dates. It's like a crossword puzzle + a history quiz.

I didn't "get gold" but I was able to get all the headline answers (but one) after a few crosses. It was fun because sometimes I knew what the headline was referring to (e.g., July 21, 1969 or, Oct. 30, 1929, or April 16, 1912) but still needed crosses to answer, and others I had no idea but was able to get after some crosses (e.g., July 1, 1958 or, Dec. 6, 1933)

This off topic, but I thought it was way too hilarious not to share as widely as possible.

You know, right, that Bad Bunny is a nepo baby?  His father was Bugs.

There‚Äôs the rub? My silent tactic reliably works for me every time. And you‚Äôre welcome to some, none or all of it. ‚ÄòTis simple; put down the ducky (the x-w puzz) and go get that 2nd cup. And when you return from the urn to the solving, if still in a cruciverbial quandary, just rinse and repeat. Get what I‚Äôm sayin,? 

Yer Welcome,

Bru
I think there's a definite split between US and non-US solvers on this one. For me the Southwest was Natick corner.

Nice to:
‚Ä¢	See LEG, EAR, and even CAN supporting the HAND theme, plus wannabe NEE in search of a K.
‚Ä¢	Have my brain engaged trying to come up with what the three theme answers had in common (with success!).
‚Ä¢	Have silliness in the grid (Hi, @M. Biggen!).  First, MRS POTATO HEAD, who makes me smile inside-out.  Second, FLAM, which by itself is fun to say and just looks goofy.  Third and most-of-all, thumbs up for CLAP-O-METER!  That's like something concocted by Jon Stewart for a bit.
‚Ä¢	Be reminded of John McPhee ‚Äì sensitive, insightful, and master of language and mood.  (Hi, @Marshall Walthew!)
‚Ä¢	Come across the PuzzPair¬©Ô∏è of SNORE and NOD.

And so, Sarah and Amie, your puzzle was not simply fill-in-and-get-on-with-the-day.  It had charm and personality.  Thank you for making it!

I might have scraped through a Wednesday level with that collection of trivia, but any harder day and I've have been utterly goosed. After my first run through the grid looked like some of my late-week efforts. Partially generally awkward trivia, partially because it's an American newspaper.

"The Times is improving how you will see replies to posts at some time in the distant future. Preview the update..."

My preference is (1) just leave them as they are, or, failing that,  (2) just go ahead and let the shoe drop.

I've also been truffling my way through the archives and I came across a Thursday from one Trenton Charlson.  December 16, 2021.  

Absolutely boffo!

Can anyone direct me to any of his previous puzzles, if known to you?

I called out to my wife as I confidently filled in UPDIKE at 44-Down. We're from Updike's home town of Shillington. I guess the precise wording of the clue should have made it clear that entry was wrong: Updike wrote only briefly "for" the New Yorker, although he appeared frequently "in" it.

A fine Tuesday, easy, but not too easy. A decent theme. I especially like the image of MRS. POTATO HEAD packing extra eyes for her husband. (Although shouldn't he be able to back his own bags at this point???) https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BBFqGHgCFiY No big surprises in the solve. But the cluing of the more traditional fill kept me on my toes.

Tuesdays are just right, not hard but not too easy. Is there really such a thing as a clap-o-meter? My sleep-o-meter says I should have stayed in bed another hour, but you know how it is.   At least I have enough brain cells for a Tuesday puzzle. We'll see about Wednesday tomorrow.

I have been an "often" READER of "The New Yorker" --even quite old issues are very readable and often arresting--but I didn't know John's surname, and it took until I had _CPHE_ for me to fill that in, as I never saw "Cabaret", didn't know the book, and had been slow to accept CLAP-O-METER.  (Srsly?)

However, cool theme, and despite more names than are desirable, a steady solve.  On with the day!  I oughtn't to brag, but I have a loaf of bread rising and 50% of the quilting done on a donation quilt.  (The Jax guild finished over 200 last year, so the goal post has been moved up.)  

It got up to 68 yesterday; the Japanese magnolias on the campus are about to bloom...given the date, I suspect they are doomed.  (Cue "Dead March.")  sigh
Thanks for a swell Tuesday grid, Sarah and Amie! I enjoyed seeing MAKEOVER and GETSINSHAPE crossing with IMAGE!

Loved the puzzle - perfectly Tuesdayish. I‚Äôm also really enjoying Myk‚Äôs columns. Please keep them coming! 

Happy day solver community! As they say in the socials - I‚Äôm here for the comments. XW people are so witty & clever!

Body part that may have a ring or a stud? Wow, there are so many (so I've been told).
Thankfully, being only 3 letters did kind of narrow it down... lip, came to mind for me. The Korean girl at the local WalMart Vision Center sports a vast display of rings and studs, in addition to her tats. And those are just the ones we can see.

That was a sweet Tuesday, filled quickly, interesting stuff (TIL VOX is also a news site, I got it through VOX Pop).
The specifically American answers will always slow me up (bakers, college names etc etc) but today the crossings were kind.
A big HAND to the constructors.

Maybe someday it will stop raining here, but not today. I read on the BBC that in my part of the world it‚Äôs rained every single day since the 1st January. We‚Äôre a wet Island yes, but this is taking the Mickey.
Clunky theme, milquetoast cluing, some natick areas. Overall a fine Tuesday though not without issue. Have a good one.

I had to read, "Coming Into the Country" for a civics requirement to graduate from college. Along with "Giants in the Earth" and Aldo Leopold.  It was such a great class! Thank you John Dizikes!  I laughed out loud at this answer. I thought this puzzle was fun.

I generally dislike musicals, but I did like "Holiday INN" for some reason. Irving Berlin notably stayed away from traditional holiday music and wrote his own, so he could collect royalties on the off chance that they became popular. He knocked it out of the park with "White Christmas," which also won the Oscar for Best Original Song.
Film-Elam?  What does that mean?

One more puzzle find. One of the most unusual I've ever encountered. A Sunday from December 10, 1995 by Jim Page with the title "Clueless." And that described the theme answers in that one. They did not have any worded clues. Here they are: 21a: GAMBLERSCARDGAME 50a: STATECAPITALS 77a: TVSUNSETSTRIP 112a: FIFTYSIXTIMESTWO 13d: ROMANXIII 76d: TROMBONES Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=12/10/1995&g=77&d=A ....
Just was NOT allowed to comment on the news today so came here to say hi!

Yawn. Very bare-minimum theme. This took two people? 
Congrats anyway :)
Missed my three-day in a row PB by just a few seconds!
Now that song is stuck in my head. I had hid it in the far reaches. Thanks for a relaxing puzzle with some enjoyable clues.

This may not be the correct place for my question but I hope someone at NYT Games can provide an answer.  Which dictionary is being used to decide the acceptability of words in Crossplay, please?  In one of today's games, my opponent entered ABA and this resulted in AA as well.  It seems to me that some players are conjuring words out of thin air and they're being accepted.   Someone else entered JUDY and it was accepted.   IVOR not OK, though!!

Usually I strictly follow the rules of my puzzle poem,‚Äôbut today I took some liberties. The title is not from the puzzle and I added the word ‚Äúagain‚Äù at the end (not in the answers). But I was just in California over the weekend admiring Mt. Tamalpais and when ‚Äúmountain‚Äù appeared in the across clues I decided to loosen the rules.

tamalpais

a/ here written in the mountain
in lines
some part of a journey
i‚Äôm packing for
d/ california
who once named me lover
your instrument paths
whistle the song of this land
and where daybreak hits
the hand splits
a/ over me again
That was a lot of fun! It somehow felt slightly tougher than usual for a Tuesday, but it was worth it for the fun theme! I also enjoyed Myq's commentary and look forward to more!
Clever. Mcphee and HSN was definitely brutal
Mr. Lehrer, registering high on the Copenhagen Clap-o-meter: https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=I9C2v1oLXQo&list=RDI9C2v1oLXQo&start_radio=1&pp=ygUjdG9tIGxlaHJlciBpIGhvbGQgeW91ciBoYW5kIGluIG1pbmWgBwE%3D
I don't know if it was just me, but this was too literal (even for a Tuesday) and joyless. Thanks anyway
I hated this puzzle. Etail? C'mon.
I‚Äôm managing to keep my streak while traveling through Australia.

Clearly this was constructed over a year ago. 47A and 68A are dated. üòñ

‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è
I liked it.

Anyone else think ‚ÄúSicily!‚Äù  For the ‚ÄúPicture it‚Äù clue? 

Or am I the only Golden Girl here? üòÇ

ERA, RAE, EAR in the same puzzle

Cool

Next time go for ARE and REA too!
@Barry Ancona https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=2/10/2026

a a,
I trust you read the Constructor notes there. 
(A bit different from the notes here!)
This thread would be easier to follow if the comments appeared in posting order (as they used to be before "improvements" were made).
And the post order changes depending upon how and when you look at the thread. Great!

@Barry Ancona

We've gone into asynchronicity.

@Barry Ancona

Someone later mentioned that the "new"-ish version of the comments has made its way to the Chrome browser, but on my Mac/Safari browser I'm still seeing the old format with newer replies appearing lower on the list (still have the options of sorting by newest or oldest).

JayTee,
This is something other than the "new" version available to try as an option forever now. In that "new" version, you don't see all of the replies unless you click on posts to which they reply. Here, now, all replies are visible but their order keeps changing.

But now it has -- for me, anyway -- turned into the "new" formerly optional version.
Another improvement that makes the threads harder to follow.

@Jacqui J

Too funny!
I had no recollection of this.
Thanks for posting!

@Jacqui J
Oh, that was Jill Eikenberry...I loved her in L.A. Law!
John McPhee has been a favorite of mine ever since buying "The Deltoid Pumpkin Seed" 50+ years ago in a Cape Cod bookstore. I've read nearly all of his work since.

Fun fact ‚Äì McPhee, has taught non-fiction writing at Princeton for more than 50 years, and one of his students was David Remnick, editor-and-chief of The New Yorker, the magazine McPhee has long been associated with.

@Lewis

Quite a lineage!

userLocation: US rules: Don't get sick. Don't get old.
commentBody:
@Marshall Walthew
What you said, and more! In his latest books, he is revealing the back stories of earlier books such as "Oranges" and his writing techniques. Like all his work, worth reading even if you think you have no conceivable interest in the spparent topic.

@Steve L If [Bird] can be an accurate clue for EAGLE, then [Formerly known as] can be an accurate clue for NEE. ‚ÄúBird‚Äù is a more general term than ‚ÄúEagle‚Äù, and ‚Äúformerly known as‚Äù is a more general term than ‚Äúnee‚Äù.

The link between clue and answer is never a two-way guarantee of equivalence.

@Gavin 279 appearances of EAGLE; [Bird] has never been the clue. Here are some: Bird on Mexican flag Sharp=eyed bird Bird depicted on a rare penny Bird on U.S. money Bird on the Great Seal of the United States https://www.xwordinfo.com/Finder On the other hand NEE's previous clue was [Called on one's birthday?} A far better clue. One that avoids the problem: [French word between two surnames]. There's OK, and there's better. I am betting you can distinguish the difference.
@Steve L The clue for NEE is fine. https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/n%C3%A9e meaning #2

@Steve L

Yeah.

You may be almost of an age of "Wide World of Sports"..."the thrill of victory, and the agony of defeat".

Vonn's legacy will contain many of both.

Yet, it now occurs to me that that makes the athlete even more endearing--think Bill Buckner or "Ali is down!  Ali is down!"
@Norbr. With you there. Sometimes it‚Äôs the little American references that get us, but cannot reasonably complain.
*American

userLocation: US rules: Don't get sick. Don't get old.

commentBody:
@Andrzez

The students at the university I taught put together a sketch comedy show and one of them did a hilarious bit about said act.  

Every time he referred to it he used a different idiom, and it was hilarious.

Especially at the end, when he mentioned his mom was in the first row.
Oops, actually that was a different episode. But both classic Seinfeld.

@Andrzej

In (American) English, we have "spanking the monkey".

Amazing how many euphemisms there are for that activity...or maybe it's not so surprising after all.
I'll let the curious google for more, if they're interested.

@SP "You're soaking in it!" I haven't thought of that commercial in years -- loved Madge! There should be a puzzle theme for some of those great ad chestnuts, but, alas, only those of us from a certain generation would likely get them.

@The X-Phile

"spanking the monkey", "shining the pole", "chocking the rooster"...

But do you know what.  All of these are from guys.  Where's the rest?

Is there a secret vault of jargon out there of which I'm completely unaware?  

Is my heart strong enough to survive it if there were?

@Francis

You mean terms referring to women, as in petting the kitty, flicking the bean, polishing the pearl? 

Or terms women use in reference to men, such as ‚Äúhall pass‚Äù or ‚Äúthat again?‚Äù

That poor dead horse had no idea what he was starting‚Ä¶

@Heidi

üòÇüòÇüòÇ

Those are *exactly* the terms I was thinking about.  Both genders.  Huge LOL.

I could have used such information about 55 years ago.  Where were you?

I sometimes wonder if the universe is not so much interested in creating life as creating humor.  I have no idea what humor looks like without life, but I withhold judgment.

userLocation: US rules: Don't get sick. Don't get old.
commentBody:
@Francis
God, I hope not. The possibility makes me think that extinction might not be the worst outcome for our species.

userLocation: US rules: Don't get sick. Don't get old.
commentBody:
@Francis
There's a reason why porpoises sound like they're laughing.
@john ezra Also, did you not start the day with ‚ÄúGood morning Bae‚Äù?

@john ezra

Just FYI - there have been 311 different answers that end  in AE in various puzzles over time. Though a lot of the ones from the pre-Shortz era are...

...unusual, to say the least.

...

@Rich in Atlanta,

I'm sure lots of those pre-Shortz words ending in -ae are plural Latin endings, one of the many lacunae in my knowledge base and vocabulary!

@CB

I'm quite fond of the Potato Heads. When I was a child we used real potatoes, not the plastic ones that came later.
@JayTee: been there! (Well, no marriage proposals!)

@Cat Lady Margaret

Been on the poking side, and have drawn blood from veins between knuckles (not easy, probably not painless, but they didn't move and we got what we needed). Cancer patients, and the big veins were needed for chemo. Could probably not do that these days, and wouldn't‚Äîcan't see as well as I used to, and doubt that anybody would like me stabbing them multiple times just to get a little bit of blood.
@Me The mascot of the CUA in DC is the cardinal (bird), but the mascot of a Catholic university in FL, St. Leo, is Fritz the Lion.  Peace.

@Me

If you look closely at the clue for 66A you will see that [university] is not capitalized. Thus, any Catholic university is eligible to be the subject.

@ŒôŒ±œÉœâŒΩ

I found it a breeze and I didn't know half those things. I used my head.

@Teresa

Delightful.

@Andrzej

Attention all units.

We detected the "delightful" stalker in the vicinity of a post by a guy with a bunch of greek letters in his name.  (Like his posts, don't understand his name at all.)

But I digress.

Converge on this area and watch for a guy driving in a car with a really beautiful dog.  Dog responds to the name Luƒáek, or whatever weird set of letters the Poles decide to use for this one.  

Update:  It may be the dog driving.
@Francis I found it a lot easier to make a guess at Jason's name than some of the Americo-centric general knowledge clues which crossed with other Americo-centric clues,

@Peter

üòÇ

You did it!  I finally saw JASON there! 

This community is great and I'm high as hell.

It doesn't get any better than that.

@Mean Old Lady Well put! There's a movie called "The Platform" that utterly terrifies me both in its existential dread and its relevance. The basic idea is that there is a gigantic platform. At the top the best chefs in the world provide a feast. They put it on a platform. The very top tier gets to eat whatever they want for a period of time. Then the platform gets lowers to the next level. And the same thing happens over and over. Of course, at the bottom levels, there's barely anything there. The people at the top levels eat gloriously; those at the bottom barely eat at all. But every month, a gas is introduced, and the levels are scrambled. Just unforgettable. So horrible, and still more humane than our world. https://www.netflix.com/watch/81128579?source=35

I just realized I drug a relatively healthy forum thread into a nightmare of despair and gloom.

I wonder who I can blame that on.
@Mean Old Lady money says Anthro. ü§£
@Teresa I completed it faster than Monday. The comment reflected that it was a Tuesday for times crossword solvers. It would not have been one got new solvers. That‚Äôs all.

@Peter ü§£ü§£ think of us poor souls who have to think about what their various passports say their name is. 

I‚Äôve spent a lifetime explaining to various authorities that just because my names appear different doesn‚Äôt mean they are aliases. üòÄ

@ŒôŒ±œÉœâŒΩ oops 

Money=nobody

commentBody:
@Mean Old Lady
But why assume the potato 'heads' were wasted? You just wash, peel, and use in something that doesn't require perfectly regular shapes -- e.g., mashed potatoes, soup, etc. The little jabby holes for inserting eyes and ears will vanish in the cutting.

@lucky13

We probably will, but that shouldn't dim your lights even a little bit.  

Even the very best solvers were at your stage at one point.

And this sounds like Bee Ess, like something off a motivational poster, but it's true, I think:  there's something noble about accepting a true challenge, whatever form that happens to take for you.

@a

I so wanted to be an "Alvin", but I think I was a Simon.

@Francis

Simon was my favorite chipmunk.
@Andrzej yep

@Jim The comments have been so, so negative lately. We should treat our constructors with more grace. Especially for puzzles like these‚Äîfun, cute theme, challenging for some and a breeze for others. A perfect Tuesday IMO.

@Francis

P. S.  As long as he doesn't continue to write simply "Delightful".

@Jim
Then don‚Äôt read the comments if you are so sensitive. I, for one, enjoy reading his posts.

@Jim
I have often thought that these comments exist solely so that solvers can offer paeans to the constructors. Many times they are deserving of that. Other times they're not. But when someone doesn't lavish a puzzle with fulsome praise, that person is often attacked. That makes many stay away, thereby not providing a balanced assessment of a particular puzzle. 

I know I often agree with Andrzej's opinions. And there are many times I would like to post a negative review but hold back, even though I'm the resident curmudgeon of the distaff side here.

We all bring our different life experiences to these puzzles, and being a lapdog every time - as a few here are - gets very old very fast.

@Andree

Not sensitive (I would say at least less so than @Andrzej) -- I was just using his words to make a point.
I have a feeling this thread may be removed because someone may take it too far.  I hope not.

@Andrzej You‚Äôre right and you should say it. People act like someone personally insults their mother when you don‚Äôt adore a puzzle here and it‚Äôs weird. Oh no, someone‚Äôs precious comment-reading experience was interrupted with something they don‚Äôt agree with. Like grow up, people.

userLocation: US rules: Don't get sick. Don't get old.

commentBody:
@lucky13
Except nowadays you get a plastic 'potato' with holes for the bits of the body. Grandsons got one for Christmas!

@Mike

"Special ovations"?  I'm not going to stand for that.

Mike,

When an actor really does poorly, they might end up looking like Mrs. or Mr. Tomatohead.

(And if the crowd throws applesauce, that‚Äôs the opposite of on core.)

@Mike

I heard the apple gave the best on core performance.

Heidi,

I love how you think :)
The on core apples always get ovations, down at the fruit stand!

@Heidi
It was really a peeling.

@Andrzej

Really?

Oh, I get it now.  You got burned below.

I have often thought I'd make a terrible critic, because 1) I don't really usually have terribly strong opinions, and 2) when I do, they're almost never negative.  

Which makes no sense, because I'm the most negative person I know.

I do have a joke about it, but it's wildly dirty, and I don't think there are enough Greek letters to get me through it.  

As a consequence, I'd tell everyone to go see this movie or read that book, because generally speaking I don't really see true Quality.  (Have you ever read "Zen and the Art of Motorcycle Maintenance" by Robert Pirsig?  If so, you'll recognized the capitalization of "Quality".)

Any way,  I won't say I'm sorry about last night because it was an honest conversation on which we differed.

But I will say I don't enjoy conflict, and I especially don't like conflict with my friends, cyber or IRL.

Cross my heart.

@Francis

Delightful.

@Andrzej

üòÇüòÇüòÇ  That's it?

That's all you're going to post from now on?

Oh, dear, we've neutered the old bull.

@Francis

Say something more than "delightful", and I'll tell you about my devastatingly handsome blue eyes.üòÄ

@Francis

Wait!  No! No!

I didn't mean that.  I really do care.

Really!  Really! Really!  Really! Really!

Look, let's put it this way....

I think I can comfortably speak for everyone in this forum.  I mean, I'm pretty sure everyone here would be completely delighted with my speaking for them.

We were wrong.  We never should have questioned you in any way.

We, and, as I speak for everyone in this forum, are so very sorry.

**  This is as good a place as any to say that this is all in fun...this is just my peculiar sense of humor.
@Andrzej I found it exactly as delightful as you did.

but I can't until you two 
shake ( or hug) and make up.

"Refresh."

You replace a three syllable word with a ONE syllable word, and think everything is just hunky-dory, just a big ole bowl of strawberries (with sugar, I find strawberries way to tart for me, but I digress)?

You are still a few strokes from shore, my friend.

**Stepping out of character...'Cute' was brilliant.  I was wondering if you'd come up with a response that kept things going.

Genius

commentBody:
@Francis
If a musical Catherine Deneuve can't save him, we're  done!

@Nora
Me too.  Solve by myself with a nice cup of tea.

@acjones

How do you know this about *nobody*? It would drive me batty to try to work a puzzle with music playing.

@acjones

I have the jingle turned off, and I definitely just sit and solve the puzzle (usually alone, in silence, with coffee or something stronger, depending on the time of day).

@acjones 

I always do the puzzle well before dawn, in a silent house, with a 16-ounce mug of coffee and a croissant. And if I don't hear the music when I finish (always my fault for messing with the phone settings, but still) I feel a little cheated.

@acjones

Solve alone on my couch for years. 
Classical music on the radio.

Happy music plays,
but *very* quietly.
If hubby hears it. he says,
"You done did it, Darlin'!"

Just turn it down (or off) in your settings.

@acjones
Another ‚Äúno one‚Äù here. I solve in low light with a cup of coffee and no more sound than a crackling fire. And I‚Äôve long since turned off the congrats music.
@acjones - That‚Äôs so funny. I live for that game show ending!

@acjones

I usually solve on a desktop.  No music playing in the background; it would be distracting.  The little jingle is allowed to play at the end.  It doesn't bother me at all.

However, on my phone and iPad, I have it unchecked in the Settings.  There are times when I don't necessarily want it broadcast that I've been doing a crossword puzzle when I'm using a mobile device.

It's your choice.  Use the settings, Luke.

@acjones I'll add to the queue. I solve on my iMac in the quiet of early morning. With my coffee, sometimes my toast. I keep the volume on my computer turned low, but I like getting the little jingle when I've successfully solved the puzzle.

@Francis
If that's what you think, just where do you think I've been for the past few months?

userLocation: US rules: Don't get sick. Don't get old.
commentBody:
@The X-Phile
I'm sure the Potatoheads have an excellent marriage. This is an example of the principle of Division of Labour. She's good with details, so she makes lists and packs. He's a spud stud, so he hauls the bags out to the Potatomobile. While they're apart, I'm sure they're both self-reliant -- she hauls, he makes lists --  but it's nice to share the work.

@Jane Wheelaghan
QVC (Quality, Value, Convenience ) and HSN (Home Shopping Network) are cable television shopping channels, if that helps you remember them. ABA is American Bar Association, of course, and NIH is National Institutes of Health.

userLocation: US rules: Don't get sick. Don't get old.

commentBody:
Bill in Yokohama,

I remembered doing that one not too long ago. Looking back, my blue solve was similar to yours.

I‚Äôm finding 1995 puzzles brutal for general difficulty, maybe getting 2-3 golds per week, and Sat-Sun often upwards of four reveals (squares, or words when I‚Äôm lazy).

@JohnWM

Yes, the early '90s are very difficult, even Mondays and Tuesdays.

@Francis
I just read that some Ma Ga congressman wants a congressional investigation into the halftime show for reasons of lewdness, indecency and smutty lyrics. Gotta laugh at that one. I guess he never listened to Kid Rock. I never did either, just read them online.

@Francis

That‚Äôs a hare brained theory.

@Times Rita

I never gave two seconds of thought to Bad Bunny until recently, but if the Mango Maga-ot doesn't like him, he's my new favorite artist.

@Steve L

Yep.  Sad to say we live in knee-jerk times, but the pace of things is so fast that sometimes even a knee-jerk isn't fast enough.

I seriously wonder if this is one the universe's experiments on how to create life, how to create intelligence, how to create cultures, how to keep cultures from annihilating each other...

It feels like we're in a critical phase of a critical phase of a critical phase of dealing with that problem.

On the other hand, I suppose everyone perceives their time as "critical".

Francis,

"...and the times they are [always] a changin'."

@Barry Ancona

Yeah.  Comes down to Bob Dylan.

It's almost impossible for us to *not* imagine ourselves at some sort of historical inflection point. 
 
It's the historical equivalent of geocentrism.  It's all about me, and, if necessary, us.

@Barry Ancona

Being quite annoyingly eccentric about some things, in the past, obviously, somehow I got the impression that it was important to know the diaper change schedule of my son when he was just born.

So I put up a piece of paper with a pencil and over the changing area and entitled it "The times they are a'changing".

I don't think I received proper accolades for that, and, if I'm honest, it bothers me to this day that I never got proper recognition.

@Peter

It goes without saying that in an American paper, with American editors and mostly American constructors, it might not be obvious during the production of any crossword what would hit international solvers differently.

Literally nothing in this puzzle that gave you difficulty hit me as terribly difficult.  Even the things that tripped me up momentarily, which I chronicled in an earlier post, didn't seem like big deals.  

But I realize that if I lived elsewhere, American brands and such might be troublesome.
